) Travel of employees on official business is governed by applicable laws and Government-wide rules and regulations and, except as otherwise provided below, the IRS travel policies. Procedures and guidelines for the of official travel are contained in the following: (cid:

) Relocation Guidelines and Procedures (
) This section establishes policy and procedures for the performance of travel in the Office of Chief Counsel; it contains additional guidance, tion and Counsel-specific information. (
) All Counsel travel is to be authorized for essential needs only and in the most cost efficient manner. Supervisors must manage travel — not simply review vouchers for accuracy and entitlement. (
) The types of travel covered by these guidelines are listed in Exhibit together with a short description of the travel category. (

) Because the travel authority of the Office of Chief Counsel is derived from Commissioner, the selection of locations and facilities for office meetings, ferences, and training sessions within the Office of Chief Counsel shall conform to IRM
Associate Chief Counsel or Division Counsel or designees may approve an exception to the normal requirement regarding location and/or costs of the meeting, within their approved funding for (

) The Office of Chief Counsel holds a large number of meetings, and training sessions across the country in the course of carrying out its programs. The following guidance is provided to ensure that sound reasons are uniformly considered and applied when planning for these off programs. a. Meetings, conferences, and training sessions should be scheduled to minimize overnight travel and related cost (i.e., planned for a location requiring a minimum number of employees to travel/stay overnight). b. All cost comparisons to identify the lowest cost city for the meeting location must include the headquarters city. c. Whenever cost differences are negligible, the decision to use the head- quarters city should prevail. d. Perception must always be a consideration by managers and when planning off site meetings. Regardless of relative cost, other considerations, off site meetings should not be held in locations which might be considered resort locations. e. Managers at all levels, should assure that training requiring travel is essential to the employee’s performance in their present assignment or a planned investment necessary to an employee’s development and career growth. f. The Office of Chief Counsel retains the authority to determine meeting, conference, and training requirements and work directly with to use credit cards and purchase orders to secure outside facilities, contracts, and services as needed.
The types of travel covered by these guidelines are listed in Exhibit 30.5.2-1 together with a short description of the travel category.
(02-04-2009) Meetings, Conferences, and Training

a. Meetings, conferences, and training sessions should be scheduled to minimize overnight travel and related cost (i.e., planned for a location requiring a minimum number of employees to travel/stay overnight). b. All cost comparisons to identify the lowest cost city for the meeting location must include the headquarters city. c. Whenever cost differences are negligible, the decision to use the head

quarters city should prevail. d. Perception must always be a consideration by managers and executives when planning off site meetings. Regardless of relative cost, availability, other considerations, off site meetings should not be held in locations which might be considered resort locations. e. Managers at all levels, should assure that training requiring travel is essential to the employee’s performance in their present assignment or a planned investment necessary to an employee’s development and career growth. f. The Office of Chief Counsel retains the authority to determine meeting, conference, and training requirements and work directly with to use credit cards and purchase orders to secure outside facilities, contracts, and services as needed.

) This subsection provides procedures for travel authorization, arrangements, charges and reimbursement. and (

) The IRS issues a General Travel Order (GTO), authorizing Counsel under proper direction, to perform official travel and to be reimbursed. This thorization covers travel within the United States and its possessions and travel to parts of Canada under certain conditions. (
) Counsel travelers must have a Travel Authorization submitted and approved within Go
rip prior to travel. This requirement allows funds for the travel to committed within the IRS’s official accounting system. Employees may the travel authorization within Go
rip, or manually complete Form
, Manual Travel Authorization. The latter can be used only for international travel. (
) All travel must be approved in advance by an Associate Chief Counsel or Division Counsel or their designees. (
) Written justification stating the necessity for the travel to be performed be submitted to the approving official prior to input into Go
rip. (

) Transportation requests, or applications for advance of funds, will not be issued or processed prior to the receipt and approval of a completed travel thorization. Note: Employees who use the Centrally Billed Account (CBA) to procure carrier transportation tickets must submit their approved Travel to the CBA Coordinator or Designated Authorizer before SATO Travel will ticket the reservation.

Note: This guidance should be followed except when the Deputy Chief Counsel (Operations or Technical), or their designee, grants an exception at least 30 days prior to obligating funds for the use of any private or commercial facility.

rip. (

) The Office of Chief Counsel will follow the IRS rules on exemptions to the general rule on using the Government-contractor issued travel card for all travel expenses. Under those rules, the following groups of travelers are matically exempted: a. Infrequent travelers — employees who travel away from their less than twice a year b. New employees — are exempt until they obtain a Government issued travel charge card. New employees who are identified by their managers to be frequent travelers are expected to obtain and use a charge card within

business days after their entrance on duty date. c. Applicants interviewing for a job (also called invitational travelers) d. Employees with suspended or canceled Government contractor-issued travel charge cards (
) All employees who do not fall into one of the categories outlined in (

) must obtain and use a Government contractor-issued travel card unless employee obtains a specific exemption from the IRS Associate Chief Officer for Internal Financial Management. a. Any employee who wishes to apply for such an exemption must submit request to the IRS CFO Policies and Procedures office, identifying the ticular reason why the exemption is requested (e.g., religious objections the use of any type of credit card). (

) Unless a specific exemption applies, Counsel travelers should not use their own funds or personal credit cards for travel expenses such as airfare or common carrier transportation. However, there are certain other expenses where it is not necessary to use the government travel charge card: (cid:
) Vendors who do not accept the card (cid:
) Laundry/dry cleaning (cid:
) Parking (cid:
) Local transportation and taxis (cid:
) Tips (cid:
) Meals and incidental expenses that are less than $
(cid:
) Certain relocation expenses, such as real estate transactions (

) The Government contractor-issued travel charge card may only be used for official business (meaning official Government travel-related expenses). It should not be used for personal travel or other personal expenses. (
) Personal use of a Government contractor-issued travel charge card may subject an employee to discipline, up to and including removal.

a. Infrequent travelers — employees who travel away from their post-of-duty less than twice a year b. New employees — are exempt until they obtain a Government contractor- issued travel charge card. New employees who are identified by their managers to be frequent travelers are expected to obtain and use a travel charge card within

business days after their entrance on duty date. c. Applicants interviewing for a job (also called invitational travelers) d. Employees with suspended or canceled Government contractor-issued travel charge cards

The Government contractor-issued travel charge card may only be used for official business (meaning official Government travel-related expenses). It should not be used for personal travel or other personal expenses.
Personal use of a Government contractor-issued travel charge card may subject an employee to discipline, up to and including removal.
Resources, Services, and Financial (

) Employees must also take care to promptly pay all the amounts due on any Government contractor-issued travel charge card. Delinquencies in payment could result in serious discipline from management and/or suspension or cellation of the card by the contractor. (

) Counsel travelers must make all ticket reservations for official travel through RESX, the web-based self-booking travel reservation system, or the Airline Travel Office (SATO), IRS’ nationwide travel management center. IRM
, Official IRS City-to-City Travel Guide. (
) Arrangements for travel which is within the following parameters should the RESX system: (cid:
) Official government business only (cid:
) Air transportation service (cid:
) Domestic destinations or an International single destination point (cid:
) Government air fares (cid:
) Coach-class service (cid:
) Electronic tickets (e-tickets) (cid:
) Individual government travel card transactions (
) Arrangements for travel consisting of one of the following elements should made by contacting SATO: (cid:
) Booking Amtrak reservations (cid:
) Booking a restricted penalty fare (cid:
) Booking a flight on Air Tran or another smaller exception carrier (cid:
) Canceling a reservation after tickets have been issued (cid:
) Changing a reservation after tickets have been issued (cid:
) Combining official and personal travel (cid:
) Traveling within the next
hours (cid:
) Traveling with a disability and/or special need (e.g., two seats required, companion travel required, service dogs) (cid:
) Traveling to multiple international cities (cid:
) Using the Centrally Billed Account (CBA) for transportation charges (the employee does not have an Individually Billing Travel Account (IBA) (

) If an employee is exempt from the requirement to use a Government contractor-issued travel charge card, then the employee may use personal funds to purchase a common carrier transportation ticket (if the ticket costs $
or less) or use a centrally billed account (Corporate Credit Card). (
) Counsel employees must follow the procedures in IRM
, for Travel Services, regarding use of contract carriers between city pairs. (

) Travelers may upgrade at their own expense (i.e., by using frequent-flyer points to upgrade). Such upgrades do not require approval since no ment funds are used. (

) Travel by personally owned automobile (POA) can be allowed if it is geous to the Government (for example, the cost of round trip mileage being less than round trip air fare or several travelers traveling in one automobile being less than their combined round-trip air fare). a. If the employee wants to travel by automobile for personal convenience, and commercial travel would cost less, the traveler must claim the cost the round trip fare plus any other transportation costs, not the actual of mileage by POA. The round trip mileage costs must be compared to commercial cost on the travel voucher. b. The traveler is then reimbursed as if the travel had been performed by commercial means. c. Any travel time during working hours used in excess of the time needed travel commercially must be charged to annual leave or leave without (

) If a traveler has followed all procedures to obtain accommodations, and then the airline fails to provide service because of overbooking or cancellation of reservation, the traveler is responsible for collecting the repayment and ting it with their travel voucher as soon as possible. a. Government employees should not give up their seats voluntarily if so would impair the performance of their official duties, or result in a in returning to their post of duty during their official hours of duty or cost to the Government. b. If an employee chooses to voluntarily give up his or her seat and the ployee’s travel time is extended due to this, any regular work hours missed must be charged to annual leave or leave without pay. less than round trip air fare or several travelers traveling in one automobile being less than their combined round-trip air fare). a. If the employee wants to travel by automobile for personal convenience, and commercial travel would cost less, the traveler must claim the cost of the round trip fare plus any other transportation costs, not the actual cost of mileage by POA. The round trip mileage costs must be compared to the commercial cost on the travel voucher. b. The traveler is then reimbursed as if the travel had been performed by commercial means. c. Any travel time during working hours used in excess of the time needed to travel commercially must be charged to annual leave or leave without pay. (

) If a traveler has followed all procedures to obtain accommodations, and then the airline fails to provide service because of overbooking or cancellation of the reservation, the traveler is responsible for collecting the repayment and submit- ting it with their travel voucher as soon as possible. a. Government employees should not give up their seats voluntarily if doing so would impair the performance of their official duties, or result in a delay in returning to their post of duty during their official hours of duty or other cost to the Government. b. If an employee chooses to voluntarily give up his or her seat and the em- ployee’s travel time is extended due to this, any regular work hours missed must be charged to annual leave or leave without pay.
Any travel time during working hours used in excess of the time needed to travel commercially must be charged to annual leave or leave without pay.

Resources, Services, and Financial c. An employee who voluntary gives up his or her seat and complies with these restrictions may keep any compensation provided by the airline. (
) This subsection provides procedures for travel advances and the reimburse- ment of travel expenses. (
) A traveler may request an advance of funds for per diem and miscellaneous expenses expected to be incurred during the planned travel. (

) The maximum travel advance that will be approved is the total cost of the estimated number of days of per diem and the local costs for transportation (i.e., to and from the airport or train station). (
) Travel advances are processed and approved through Go
rip. Go
rip is used to approve travel and to reimburse travelers upon entry of their voucher expense information. Information about Go
rip can be found in: (cid:
) IRM
, Official IRS Local Travel Guide (cid:
) IRM
, Official IRS City-to-City Travel Guide (cid:
) Go
rip Traveler’s Toolkit (
) Travelers who have a Government contractor-issued travel charge card (see CCDM

) may request automated teller machine (ATM) privileges. a. ATM privileges can be granted if the traveler has a record of prompt payment of their travel expenses. b. Requests for ATM privileges must be approved by the Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) or his/her designee. c. ATM privileges are to be used in lieu of travel advances (

) Travelers are required to enter their voucher expense information into immediately following their return from travel status. Detailed information regarding how claims for reimbursement of expenses are to be filed may be found on that system or in IRM
and/or IRM
. Managers the expenses in Go
rip, and reimbursement is made via Electronic Fund Transfer (EFT) to the traveler’s bank account. (

) Travelers can be reimbursed for subway, bus, limousine, or taxi fares (including tips) to and from the airport or station and post of duty, residence, hotel. These costs are not included in the per diem rate and are claimed rately on the travel voucher. In the interest of economy, subways, buses or limousines should be used in lieu of taxis wherever possible. (

) Travelers can be reimbursed for the use of privately owned automobiles from residence or post of duty to the airport or train station and return, in lieu of local transportation, if the cost of mileage and parking fees, if any, do not exceed the cost by commercial means. Current rates are provided at the Employee Resource Center (ERC) website. (

) Per diem is a rate of reimbursement established annually by GSA. Per diem provided in lieu of a detailed submission of expenses covering meals, tips and other miscellaneous expenses. Information on the most current per diem rates can be found via the ERC website or http://www.gsa.gov/.

) Actual expenses can be authorized when the actual and/or necessary tence expenses exceed the maximum per diem allowance by
% or more of Actual and the traveler has no alternative but to incur hotel costs which absorb all nearly all of the maximum per diem allowance. (
) The authority to approve actual expenses for travel, with the exception of foreign travel, is delegated to the Associates Chief Counsel and Division Counsels (see Delegation Order
, Reimbursement for Actual Expenses, IRM

, Delegation of Authority for Organization, Finance and ment Activities). When the unusual circumstances of the travel assignment justify the decision, the Associates Chief Counsel and Division Counsels, or their designees, may: a. Authorize or approve reimbursement for subsistence expenses on an actual expense basis b. Authorize, in advance of performance of travel, appropriate per diem al- lowances in lieu of actual subsistence reimbursement for travel to high rate geographical areas (

) The Associate Chief Counsel (F&M) is authorized to approve changes in of duty (relocation) at Government expense. Information on relocation allow- At ances is found in IRM
,Relocation Services Program. Expense (
) Counsel employees authorized to relocate should contact their officers to initiate the appropriate paperwork and procedures. (

, for Official Travel. (

Resources, Services, and Financial Management
Resources, Services, and Financial (
) Any office contemplating official foreign travel by an employee under their diction should send the Associate Chief Counsel (International) a stating:
The purpose of the travel
The country or countries to be visited
The complete itinerary
Whether an official passport is required
An estimate of the travel expenses (transportation, per diem, and other) Note: This memorandum should be received by the Associate Chief Counsel national) in sufficient time (at least
work days) to allow for securing the necessary approvals and the processing of a passport application, if required. (

) Chief Counsel employees traveling to foreign countries on official business must obtain a valid United States official passport. A regular tourist passport not appropriate for official travel. a. The Department of State does not object to the use of an official for incidental personal travel by personnel going to or from an abroad, provided the foreign governments concerned do not object to use of the passport for unofficial travel. However, if the personal travel planned is extensive, the traveler must obtain a tourist passport. b. A person may simultaneously possess both a valid tourist passport and valid official passport. If an official passport is required, the office will for the expenses associated with obtaining one. c. Questions regarding these procedures should be addressed to the of Associate Chief Counsel (International). (

) Counsel employees may retain for personal use promotional items received during the course of an official business trip if such items are obtained under Items, the same conditions as those offered to the general public at no additional Frequent Flyer to the Government. (
) These guidelines apply to any promotional items received by employees in past or to be earned or received in the future. (

) Promotional benefits include free tickets and upgrades obtained through the redemption of accumulated frequent flier mileage points, hotel and car rental coupons, etc. Travelers are responsible for tracking their own Any costs associated with establishing a frequent flier account are personal expenses which are borne by the employee. (
) An employee cannot travel by non-contract carrier solely to earn more points with that carrier, even if the non-contract carrier offers a matching (
) As explained in CCDM

, all frequent travelers must use the ment contractor-issue travel charge card. Therefore, a traveler should not charge an airline ticket or other expense, which should be charged to the ernment card, to a personal credit card in order to take advantage of points and other benefits obtainable through the personal card. The Department of State does not object to the use of an official for incidental personal travel by personnel going to or from an abroad, provided the foreign governments concerned do not object to use of the passport for unofficial travel. However, if the personal travel planned is extensive, the traveler must obtain a tourist passport. A person may simultaneously possess both a valid tourist passport and valid official passport. If an official passport is required, the office will pay for the expenses associated with obtaining one. Questions regarding these procedures should be addressed to the office of Associate Chief Counsel (International).
An employee cannot travel by non-contract carrier solely to earn more mileage points with that carrier, even if the non-contract carrier offers a matching fare.
page (

) The Office of Chief Counsel has a Travel Gainsharing program which employees who save government money through their own initiative. This is voluntary program that operates under the guidelines below. (
) Counsel employees on official travel may receive cash awards of
% of the combined savings from the following five categories: (cid:
) Lodging costs that are less than the locality rate (cid:
) Sharing a hotel room with one other government traveler (each traveler
saves of the single daily lodging rate times the number of days)
(cid:
) Staying with friends or family which results in zero lodging costs (cid:
) Using frequent flyer miles accumulated from government or personal to purchase an airline ticket for official use (cid:

) Traveling on his/her own time to/from official training programs or wide meetings (with prior management approval) if the employee attends the entire program or meeting and reports to duty the day following the conclusion of the program or meeting Example: One night’s lodging cost can be claimed if an employee goes to a training class ending at

p.m. on Thursday but the employee gets mission to travel home Thursday night and, therefore, incurs no additional lodging costs and reports to work on Friday morning instead traveling home on Friday. (
) All Counsel employees on official travel status, either foreign or domestic, save a minimum of $
per fiscal year, are eligible for Travel Gainsharing awards of
% of the savings. Example: An employee who saves a combined total of $
in lodging and tickets during the fiscal year will receive $
at the end of the fiscal year. The employee will receive a SF
showing the award amount the amount will be included on the employee’s Form W-
Taxes and other applicable deductions will be withheld from the award amount. (
) Employees must comply with all travel requirements in IRM
, ing Travel Savings Program, in order to qualify for the award. (
) Employees have the responsibility to track savings and submit Form
, Travel Savings Form – Office of Chief Counsel, with each travel voucher where savings have resulted. Once an employee’s aggregate savings reach exceed $
, the employee should notify their manager that the $
minimum savings has been reached and he/she is now eligible for a Travel Gainsharing Award which will be payable in total after the end of the current fiscal year. (

) Employees on travel during the last two weeks of the fiscal year should their forms within two weeks after the end of the fiscal year. Employees who do not submit completed forms timely will not receive awards for those (

) The following exclusions apply: a. Relocation travel is not covered under this program. b. No Gainsharing awards will result from weekend travel to an alternate location. c. Awards will not be made to individual employees on travel where savings were the result of being prearranged by someone else or by contract with the hotel. (

Awards will not be made to individual employees on travel where savings were the result of being prearranged by someone else or by contract with the hotel.
Employees must comply with all travel requirements in IRM 1.32.14, ing Travel Savings Program, in order to qualify for the award.

Employees have the responsibility to track savings and submit Form 13631, Travel Savings Form – Office of Chief Counsel, with each travel voucher filed where savings have resulted. Once an employee’s aggregate savings reach exceed $100, the employee should notify their manager that the $100 minimum savings has been reached and he/she is now eligible for a Travel Gainsharing Award which will be payable in total after the end of the current fiscal year.

Relocation travel is not covered under this program. No Gainsharing awards will result from weekend travel to an alternate location. Awards will not be made to individual employees on travel where lodging savings were the result of being prearranged by someone else or prepaid by contract with the hotel.
10 30.5 Resources, Services, and Financial Management

d. Hotel lodging costs must be paid with the government contractor issued travel card in order to qualify for inclusion under this program. e. Lodging costs incurred on personal time such as leave will not be counted as savings under this program.
